The following transcripts of dialogues have been taken from Shakespeare plays, but the transcripts do not say who said what.  Your task is to identify whether the sentences in question were spoken by the same or different people.
Dialogue:
I pray you, sir, what saucy merchant was this that was so full of his ropery? A knave; a rascal; an eater of broken meats; a base, proud, shallow, beggarly, three-suited, hundred-pound, filthy worsted-stocking knave; a lily-livered, action-taking knave; a whoreson, glass-gazing, super-serviceable finical rogue; one-trunk-inheriting slave; one that wouldst be a bawd in way of good service, and art nothing but the composition of a knave, beggar, coward, pandar, and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch: one whom I will beat into clamorous whining if thou deniest the least syllable of thy addition.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "A knave; a rascal; an eater of broken meats; a base, proud, shallow, beggarly, three-suited, hundred-pound, filthy worsted-stocking knave; a lily-livered, action-taking knave; a whoreson, glass-gazing, super-serviceable finical rogue; one-trunk-inheriting slave; one that wouldst be a bawd in way of good service, and art nothing but the composition of a knave, beggar, coward, pandar, and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch:" and "I pray you, sir, what saucy merchant was this that was so full of his ropery?" spoken by the same person or different people?
Answer:

The following transcripts of dialogues have been taken from Shakespeare plays, but the transcripts do not say who said what.  Your task is to identify whether the sentences in question were spoken by the same or different people.
Dialogue:
I am a Jew. Hath not a Jew eyes? hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions? fed with the same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer, as a Christian is? If you prick us, do we not bleed? if you tickle us, do we not laugh? if you poison us, do we not die? and if you wrong us, shall we not revenge? If we are like you in the rest, we will resemble you in that.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "Hath not a Jew eyes? hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions? fed with the same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer, as a Christian is?" and "If you prick us, do we not bleed? if you tickle us, do we not laugh? if you poison us, do we not die? and if you wrong us, shall we not revenge?" spoken by the same person or different people?
Answer:

The following transcripts of dialogues have been taken from Shakespeare plays, but the transcripts do not say who said what.  Your task is to identify whether the sentences in question were spoken by the same or different people.
Dialogue:
I am one, sir, that comes to tell you your daughter and the Moor are now making the beast with two backs. Thou art a villain. You are--a senator. This thou shalt answer; I know thee, Roderigo. Sir, I will answer any thing. But, I beseech you, If't be your pleasure and most wise consent, As partly I find it is, that your fair daughter, At this odd-even and dull watch o' the night, Transported with no worse nor better guard But with a knave of common hire, a gondolier, To the gross clasps of a lascivious Moor-- If this be known to you and your allowance, We then have done you bold and saucy wrongs;
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "Thou art a villain." and "You are--a senator." spoken by the same person or different people?
Answer:

Dialogue:
By good Euriphile, our mother. Be't so: And let us, Polydore, though now our voices Have got the mannish crack, sing him to the ground, As once our mother; use like note and words, Save that Euriphile must be Fidele. Cadwal, I cannot sing: I'll weep, and word it with thee; For notes of sorrow out of tune are worse Than priests and fanes that lie. We'll speak it, then.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "By good Euriphile, our mother." and "Cadwal, I cannot sing: I'll weep, and word it with thee; For notes of sorrow out of tune are worse Than priests and fanes that lie. We'll speak it, then." spoken by the same person or different people?
Answer:

The following transcripts of dialogues have been taken from Shakespeare plays, but the transcripts do not say who said what.  Your task is to identify whether the sentences in question were spoken by the same or different people.
Dialogue:
I am sorry that with better heed and judgment I had not quoted him: I fear'd he did but trifle, And meant to wrack thee; but beshrew my jealousy! It seems it was his pleasure, thus to leave me: She speaks much of her father; says she hears There's tricks i' the world; and hems, and beats her heart; Spurns enviously at straws; speaks things in doubt, That carry but half sense: her speech is nothing, Yet the unshaped use of it doth move The hearers to collection; they aim at it, And botch the words up fit to their own thoughts; Which, as her winks, and nods, and gestures yield them, Indeed would make one think there might be thought, Though nothing sure, yet much unhappily.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "I am sorry that with better heed and judgment I had not quoted him: I fear'd he did but trifle, And meant to wrack thee; but beshrew my jealousy!" and "She speaks much of her father; says she hears There's tricks i' the world; and hems, and beats her heart;" spoken by the same person or different people?
Answer:

Dialogue:
I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul. My name is not Amanda, nor am I a witch; but being born under Saturn, I have a melancholy spirit, and I think that's as good a way as any to explain why I am so different from other people. I don't like to talk much, and when I do, I try to make it count. I don't like to be touched, either, except by my husband, and even then only when I am in the mood for it. I don't know why I am telling you all this. You are a stranger to me, and yet I feel as if I have known you all my life.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul." and "I don't like to talk much, and when I do, I try to make it count." spoken by the same person or different people?
Answer:

I pray thee, let me look on that again. Behold, upon thy cheek the stain doth sit Of an old tear that is not washed off yet: If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine, Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline: And art thou changed? Pronounce this sentence then, Women may fall, when there's no strength in men.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "I pray thee, let me look on that again." and "If e'er thou wast thyself and these woes thine, Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline: And art thou changed?" spoken by the same person or different people?

Dialogue:
I am not bound to please thee with my answers. My life is mine own, and so is my estate; If he that owns the land thou dost usurp Would yield it up to thee, then thou mightst plead A title to it; but since none will yield, And thou hast none to show, why, hang thyself! He that would make his own liberty secure Must guard even his enemy from oppression; For if he violates this duty, he establishes A precedent that will reach to himself.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "I am not bound to please thee with my answers. My life is mine own, and so is my estate;" and "He that would make his own liberty secure Must guard even his enemy from oppression; For if he violates this duty, he establishes A precedent that will reach to himself." spoken by the same person or different people?
Answer:

I am afeard there are few die well that die in a battle; for how can they charitably dispose of anything when blood is their argument? Now, if these men do not die well, it will be a black matter for the king that led them to it; whom to disobey were against all proportion of subjection.

I warrant you, mistress, thunder shall not so awake the beds of eels as my giving out her beauty stir up the lewdly-inclined. What, will you make a younker of me? Shall I not take mine ease in mine inn but I shall have my pocket picked? I have lost a seal-ring of my grandfather's worth forty mark. O Jesu, I have heard the prince tell him, I know not how oft, that that ring was copper! How? the prince is a Jack, a sneak-cup: 'sblood, an he were here, I would cudgel him like a dog, if he would say so.

I pray you, bear witness that me have stay six or seven, two tree hours for him, and he is no come. He not answer; he not appear. What say you to dat? By gar, me vill kill de priest; for he speak for a jack-an-ape to Anne Page. Let him die: sheathe thy impatience; throw cold water on thy choler: go about the fields with me through Frogmore; I will bring thee where Mistress Anne Page is, at a farm-house a-feasting; and thou shalt woo her. Cried game? said I well?

Dialogue:
I am glad I am so acquit of this tinder-box: his thefts were too open; his filching was like an unskilful singer--he kept not time. Yea, but I think he did usury with his eyes; for oaths are straws, men's faiths are wafer-cakes, and hold-fast is the only dog, my duck; therefore, caveto be thy counsellor. Well, sir, there rest in your foolery. Is there any else commanded to-night? None but the fool; who labours to out-jest His heart-struck injuries. Sir, I say to you, it is thought you are false knaves.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "Yea, but I think he did usury with his eyes; for oaths are straws, men's faiths are wafer-cakes, and hold-fast is the only dog, my duck; therefore, caveto be thy counsellor." and "I am glad I am so acquit of this tinder-box: his thefts were too open; his filching was like an unskilful singer--he kept not time." spoken by the same person or different people?
Answer:

I warrant you, sir, we will make that sure. He that escapes me without some broken limb shall acquit him well. And if he do not, i'll be sworn he is a villain. Thou art a robber, A law-breaker, a villain: yield thee, thief. To whom? to thee? What art thou? Have not I An arm as big as thine? a heart as big? Thy words, I grant, are bigger, for I wear not My dagger in my mouth. Say what thou art, Why I should yield to thee. Thou villain base, Know'st me not by my clothes? No, nor thy tailor, rascal, Who is thy grandfather: he made those clothes,
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "Thou art a robber, A law-breaker, a villain: yield thee, thief." and "To whom? to thee? What art thou?" spoken by the same person or different people?

I am not a slut, though I thank the gods I am foul. I am foul two ways: one is because I am not fair; the other is because I am not a bird. Thou hast most kindly hit it. Well said, i'faith, neighbour Verges. Well, well, we shall have him: he is a very good neighbourly man, and fits his word to his own bond: he does not falter. No, thou villain, thou art full of piety, as shall be proved upon thee by good witness. I am a wise fellow, and which is more, an officer, and which is more, a householder, and which is more, as pretty a piece of flesh as any is in Messina, and one that knows the law, go to; and a rich fellow enough, go to; and a fellow that hath had losses, and one that hath two gowns and every thing handsome about him.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "No, thou villain, thou art full of piety, as shall be proved upon thee by good witness." and "Well, well, we shall have him: he is a very good neighbourly man, and fits his word to his own bond: he does not falter." spoken by the same person or different people?
Answer:

Dialogue:
I pray you, sir, use the carp as you may; for he looks like a poor, decayed, ingenious, foolish, rascally knave. I do beseech you, good Sir John, let me send quickly to Sir John Falstaff: I will fetch him and he shall answer by the law; I warrant you. Mistress Page is come with me, sweetheart. Divide me like a bribe buck, each a haunch: I will keep my sides to myself, my shoulders for the fellow of this walk, and my horns I bequeath your husbands. Am I a woodman? Ha! Speak I like Herne the hunter? Why, now is Cupid a child of conscience; he makes restitution. As I am a true spirit, welcome!
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "I pray you, sir, use the carp as you may; for he looks like a poor, decayed, ingenious, foolish, rascally knave." and "I do beseech you, good Sir John, let me send quickly to Sir John Falstaff: I will fetch him and he shall answer by the law; I warrant you." spoken by the same person or different people?

Dialogue:
I am not bound to please thee with my answers. I will not be sworn but love may transform me to an oyster; but I'll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster of me, he shall never make me such a fool. One woman is fair, yet I am well; another is wise, yet I am well; another virtuous, yet I am well; but till all graces be in one woman, one woman shall not come in my grace. Rich she shall be, that's certain; wise, or I'll none; virtuous, or I'll never cheapen her; fair, or I'll never look on her; mild, or come not near me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good discourse, an excellent musician, and her hair shall be of what colour it please God. Ha! the prince and Monsieur Love! I will hide me in the arbour.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "I am not bound to please thee with my answers." and "One woman is fair, yet I am well; another is wise, yet I am well; another virtuous, yet I am well; but till all graces be in one woman, one woman shall not come in my grace." spoken by the same person or different people?

I pray you, bear witness that me have stay six or seven, two tree hours for him, and he is no come. He not answer; he not speak; he not spit; he not move; he not groan. Ay, and beseech you to look into his pedegree: for my own part, I know not the degree of the Worthy; but I will warrant him, as gentle as a lamb. Go you, and see where he is, look if he be master of his own rage; if he be, it is a wonder, no villainous bounty yet hath passed my heart; so far, that I detest all manner of wickedness.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "I pray you, bear witness that me have stay six or seven, two tree hours for him, and he is no come. Dialogue:
I am one, sir, that comes to tell you your daughter and the Moor are now making the beast with two backs. I will be hang'd, if some eternal villain, Some busy and insinuating rogue, Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office, Have not devised this slander; I'll be hang'd else.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "I am one, sir, that comes to tell you your daughter and the Moor are now making the beast with two backs." and "I will be hang'd, if some eternal villain, Some busy and insinuating rogue, Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office, Have not devised this slander; I'll be hang'd else." spoken by the same person or different people?
Answer:

I warrant you, my lord, the duke will not hear your displeasure: to-morrow morning are you--come, my lord-- And you, my noble lord, come you to-night: and bring me word what he will do. I warrant you, madam, we will make that sure. I warrant thee; stand thee close then under this penthouse, for it drizzles rain; and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to thee. Mark me. In requital whereof, henceforth carry his picture about thee; to the end thy eye, being big with tears, may dwell upon the image and fall of tears. When thou hast done this, rattle like an adder in the ear of death: "No more of him; he's dead, he's dead, he's dead;"

Dialogue:
I am a man more sinned against than sinning. I will be gone; My being here it is that holds thee hence: Shall I stay here to do't? no, no, although The air of paradise did fan the house, And angels offic'd all: I will be gone, That pitiful rumour may report my flight To consolate thine ear. Come, night; end, day!

Dialogue:
I pray you, bear witness that me have stay six or seven, two tree hours for him, and he is no come. He not answer; he not speak; he not spit; he not move; he not groan. Ay, spy. What art thou? Who art thou? O unhappy youth! Come not within these doors; within this roof The enemy of all your graces lives: Your brother--no, no brother; yet the son-- Yet not the son, I will not call him son Of him I was about to call his father-- Hath heard your praises; and this night he means To burn the lodging where you use to lie, And you within it: if he fail of that, He will have other means to cut you off.
In the preceding dialogue, were the lines "I pray you, bear witness that me have stay six or seven, two tree hours for him, and he is no come. He not answer; he not speak; he not spit; he not move; he not groan." and "Ay, spy. What art thou? Who art thou?" spoken by the same person or different people?
Answer:

Dialogue:
I warrant thee, if I do not act it, hiss me. Thou wilt not? Then, like a melancholy lover, Pardon me, I will do nothing: but I will sing you a song. Ay, sing, and you had been a bird, I would have sung you to an oyster; I would have been sworn you had been a maid. Oysters may be traced back to ancient Rome, where they were considered a delicacy and were often served at banquets. The Romans believed that eating oysters could increase a man's virility.

I am sorry that I am deceived in him. Why, he comes in like a perjure, wearing papers. In time I may believe, yet I mistrust. Mistrust it not: for sure, AEacides Was Ajax,--call'd so from his grandfather. I must believe my master; else, I promise you, I should be arguing still upon that doubt: But let it rest. Come, sir, I will make amends hereafter, if any ill word hath been spoke now. Will you dismiss me? Dear sir, forbear.

I am not bound to please thee with my answers. My dear lord, if you be so minded, let the peccant scions of my disobedience take root, to the confusion of posterity. I will not reprove you; but, for your own sake, I am glad of your departure: believe me, my lord, I have had a most weak and puling melancholy, which I would fain have battened with some countenance or other: but it is gone. Patience, good sir, do not assist the storm. The foul fiend bites my back. Foul fiend!

Dialogue:
I am a Jew. Hath not a Jew eyes? hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions? fed with the same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer, as a Christian is? If you prick us, do we not bleed? if you tickle us, do we not laugh? if you poison us, do we not die? and if you wrong us, shall we not revenge?
